title: Kind of Blue
description: The best-selling jazz album of all time, a landmark in modal jazz featuring an all-star ensemble including John Coltrane and Bill Evans.

title: The Freewheelin' Bob Dylan
description: Dylan's breakthrough album of original songs, featuring protest anthems like 'Blowin' in the Wind' and 'A Hard Rain's A-Gonna Fall'.

title: Please Please Me
description: The Beatles' debut album, recorded in a single day, capturing the raw energy of their live Cavern Club performances.

title: A Love Supreme
description: A four-part suite and spiritual meditation widely regarded as Coltrane's masterpiece and one of the greatest jazz recordings ever made.

title: Rubber Soul
description: The album that signaled The Beatles' artistic maturity, blending folk, pop, and early psychedelia with introspective lyrics.

title: Pet Sounds
description: Brian Wilson's orchestral pop masterpiece, a deeply personal album that redefined the possibilities of studio production.

title: Revolver
description: A revolutionary album pushing rock music into new sonic territory with tape loops, backwards recording, and orchestral arrangements.

title: The Velvet Underground & Nico
description: Lou Reed and John Cale's confrontational debut produced by Andy Warhol, exploring taboo subjects that would influence generations of artists.

title: Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band
description: The Beatles' psychedelic concept album, a watershed moment in popular music that pioneered the studio album as an art form.

title: Are You Experienced
description: Hendrix's explosive debut introducing the world to his virtuosic guitar technique, combining blues, rock, and psychedelia.

title: The Doors
description: A menacing debut built around Ray Manzarek's organ and Jim Morrison's dark, literary poetry, including the epic 'The End'.

title: Forever Changes
description: Arthur Lee's orchestral folk-rock masterpiece, a lush and melancholic album widely considered one of the finest of the 1960s.

title: Astral Weeks
description: A stream-of-consciousness suite blending folk, jazz, and classical music into an intensely spiritual and deeply personal work.

title: Electric Ladyland
description: Hendrix's sprawling double-album masterpiece, demonstrating his full range as a guitarist, songwriter, and studio innovator.

title: Abbey Road
description: The Beatles' final recorded album, featuring the iconic side-two medley and a stunning display of songwriting craftsmanship.

title: Led Zeppelin II
description: A relentless hard rock blueprint featuring 'Whole Lotta Love', cementing Led Zeppelin as the defining heavy rock band of their era.

title: Bitches Brew
description: Miles Davis's electric double album that fused jazz with rock and funk rhythms, launching the jazz fusion genre.

title: After the Gold Rush
description: Neil Young's breakthrough solo album balancing raw acoustic folk with electric rock, featuring environmentalist themes.

title: What's Going On
description: Marvin Gaye's socially conscious masterpiece addressing Vietnam, poverty, and ecological destruction through lush orchestral soul.

title: Exile on Main St.
description: Recorded in a rented French villa, this sprawling double album captures the Stones at their most raw and spontaneously brilliant.

title: The Dark Side of the Moon
description: Pink Floyd's meditation on time, greed, and mental illness, one of the best-selling albums of all time and a studio production landmark.

title: Innervisions
description: Stevie Wonder's socially aware funk-soul classic, part of his extraordinary run of 1970s albums played almost entirely by himself.

title: Horses
description: Patti Smith's debut fuses poetry and punk rock into a bold artistic statement, produced by John Cale and opening with a reimagining of 'Gloria'.

title: Blood on the Tracks
description: Dylan's devastating breakup album widely regarded as his greatest work, featuring raw storytelling of love and loss.

title: Born to Run
description: Springsteen's cinematic breakthrough, an operatic rock album capturing working-class dreams of escape and transcendence.

title: Rumours
description: Recorded amid the collapse of multiple band relationships, this polished pop-rock album became one of the best-selling albums ever made.

title: Never Mind the Bollocks, Here's the Sex Pistols
description: The definitive punk statement, a 38-minute explosion of anger at the British establishment that transformed popular music.

title: Marquee Moon
description: Television's debut features the interlocking guitar work of Tom Verlaine and Richard Lloyd, a cornerstone of post-punk and art rock.

title: London Calling
description: The Clash's ambitious double album transcending punk to incorporate reggae, ska, rockabilly, and jazz in a passionate political statement.

title: Unknown Pleasures
description: Joy Division's debut produced by Martin Hannett, a bleak and atmospheric post-punk landmark defined by Ian Curtis's haunting vocals.

title: The Wall
description: Roger Waters's rock opera about isolation and oppression, one of the best-selling double albums in history featuring 'Another Brick in the Wall'.

title: My Life in the Bush of Ghosts
description: A pioneering work of sampling and world music collage that anticipated entire genres, blending found vocal recordings with African rhythms.

title: Nebraska
description: Springsteen's stark acoustic solo album of dark American gothic short stories, recorded at home on a four-track cassette recorder.

title: Let's Dance
description: Bowie's most commercially successful album, produced by Nile Rodgers, featuring Stevie Ray Vaughan and a sleek, danceable pop sound.

title: Purple Rain
description: The soundtrack to Prince's semi-autobiographical film, a genre-defying fusion of rock, R&B, and pop that made him a global superstar.

title: The Queen Is Dead
description: The Smiths' masterpiece balancing Morrissey's sardonic wit and romantic despair with Johnny Marr's jangly guitar brilliance.

title: Sign o' the Times
description: Prince's ambitious double album surveying crime, drugs, AIDS, and love through an astonishing range of funk, soul, rock, and pop styles.

title: Isn't Anything
description: My Bloody Valentine's debut full-length established the sonic template for shoegaze with its walls of distorted, melodic guitar noise.

title: Paul's Boutique
description: A densely layered hip-hop collage produced by the Dust Brothers, sampling hundreds of records to create a kaleidoscopic audio adventure.

title: Doolittle
description: The Pixies' breakthrough album pioneering the quiet-loud dynamic that would define alternative rock, featuring 'Here Comes Your Man' and 'Debaser'.

title: Loveless
description: Kevin Shields's obsessive studio masterpiece, a tsunami of treated guitars and hushed vocals that took three years and nearly bankrupted a record label.

title: Nevermind
description: The album that brought alternative rock into the mainstream, featuring 'Smells Like Teen Spirit' and Kurt Cobain's confessional songwriting.

title: Achtung Baby
description: U2's reinvention as an ironic, industrial-influenced rock band, abandoning their earnest 1980s sound for something darker and more experimental.

title: Automatic for the People
description: R.E.M.'s elegiac and orchestral meditation on loss and mortality, widely regarded as one of the greatest albums of the 1990s.

title: OK Computer
description: Radiohead's anxious and prescient exploration of modern alienation, technology, and consumerism, recorded in a Somerset country manor.

title: The Miseducation of Lauryn Hill
description: Lauryn Hill's sole studio album blending hip-hop, neo-soul, and reggae with deeply personal lyrics about love, faith, and empowerment.

title: The Marshall Mathers LP
description: Eminem's explosive major label debut featuring Dr. Dre's production and Slim Shady's provocative, horrorcore-influenced rapping.

title: Kid A
description: Radiohead's radical departure from guitar rock into electronic and avant-garde territory, an album that defined the sound of a new decade.

title: Stankonia
description: OutKast's genre-defying double album fusing hip-hop with funk, soul, and psychedelia, featuring the massive hit 'Ms. Jackson'.

title: Is This It
description: The Strokes' debut revived garage rock for the 21st century, its stripped-down production and cool New York attitude sparking a rock renaissance.

title: In The Wee Small Hours
description: In the Wee Small Hours is the ninth studio album by the American singer Frank Sinatra, released on April 25, 1955, by Capitol Records. Produced by Voyle Gilmore with arrangements by Nelson Riddle, the album's songs deal with themes such as introspection, melancholy, lost love, failed relationships, depression and night life; as such, it has been called one of the first concept albums.

title: Ellington at Newport _56
description: This is the discography of recordings by Duke Ellington, including those nominally led by his sidemen, and his later collaborations with musicians with whom Ellington had generally not previously recorded.

title: Elvis Presley
description: Elvis Presley is the debut studio album by American rock and roll singer Elvis Presley. It was released by RCA Victor, on March 23, 1956.

title: Songs For Swingin' Lovers
description: Songs for Swingin' Lovers! is the tenth studio album by American singer Frank Sinatra, and his fourth for Capitol Records.

title: Birth of the Cool
description: Birth of the Cool is a compilation album by the American jazz trumpeter and bandleader Miles Davis. It was released in February or March 1957 on Capitol Records.

title: Tragic Songs Of Life
description: Tragic Songs of Life is the debut album by American country music duo The Louvin Brothers, released in 1956. "Knoxville Girl" was released as a single three years later and reached number 19 on the Billboard Country Singles chart.

title: The Atomic Mr Basie
description: Count Basie at Newport is a live album by jazz musician Count Basie and his orchestra. It was originally issued as Verve MGV 8243 and included only the tracks 1–7 and 13.

title: This is Fats Domino
description: Fats Domino was an American pianist and singer-songwriter. One of the pioneers of rock and roll music, more than 65 million records were sold by Domino.

title: Here_s Little Richard
description: Here's Little Richard is the debut studio album by the American musician Little Richard, released on March 4, 1957. Promoted as "six of Little Richard's hits and six brand new songs of hit calibre", the album compiles many of the A-sides and B-sides from Richard's hit singles including the Billboard top 40 entries "Tutti Frutti", "Long Tall Sally", "Slippin' and Slidin'", "Rip It Up" and "Jenny, J

title: The Wildest
description: The Wildest! is an album by Louis Prima, first released in 1956.

title: Kenya
description: Frank Grillo known professionally as Machito, was a Latin jazz musician who helped refine Afro-Cuban jazz and played a key role in the creation of both Cubop and salsa music. He was raised in Havana with his foster sister, the singer Graciela.

title: Palo Congo
description: Palo Congo is the debut album by conguero Sabú Martínez, recorded on April 27, 1957 and released on Blue Note later that year. The octet features Arsenio Rodríguez, his brothers Raúl and "Quique"—alongside Ray "Mosquito" Romero—on congas, bassist Evaristo Baró, and vocalists Willie Capó and Sarah Baró.

title: The _Chirping_ Crickets
description: The "Chirping" Crickets is the only studio album credited to the American rock and roll band the Crickets from the period when they were led by Buddy Holly. It was also the only album released under the group's name during Holly's lifetime.

title: Brilliant Corners
description: Brilliant Corners is a 1957 studio album by American jazz pianist Thelonious Monk. It was his third album for Riverside Records, and his first on the label to include his own compositions.

title: Lady in Satin
description: Lady in Satin is an album by the jazz singer Billie Holiday, released in 1958 on Columbia Records, catalogue CL 1157 in mono and CS 8048 in stereo. It is the penultimate album completed by the singer, and the last to be released in her lifetime.

title: Jack Takes the Floor
description: Jack Takes the Floor is an album by American folk musician Ramblin' Jack Elliott, released in Great Britain in 1958. The original release was a 10-inch LP.

title: Live at Mister Kelly_s
description: The albums discography of American jazz artist Sarah Vaughan contains 48 studio albums, ten live albums, 35 compilation albums, two extended plays, five box sets and eight album appearances. Her debut studio album was issued in 1950 and was followed by her second self-titled studio recording was released on EmArcy Records in 1954.

title: Dance Mania
description: Dance Mania is a studio album by American musician Tito Puente. The album was added to the National Recording Registry in 2002.

title: Time Out
description: Time Out is a studio album by the American jazz group the Dave Brubeck Quartet, released in 1959 by Columbia Records. Recorded at Columbia’s 30th Street Studio in New York City, the album is noted for its pioneering use of unconventional time signatures for jazz, including 98, 64, and 54.

title: George Gershwin Songbook
description: With the introduction of 10" and 12" Long-Playing records in the late 1940s, Decca released several original albums of Fitzgerald's music and reissued many of her previous releases. From 1935 to the late 1940s Decca issued Ella Fitzgerald's recordings on 78rpm singles and album collections, in book form, of four singles that included eight tracks.

title: Gunfighter Ballads And Trail Songs
description: Gunfighter Ballads and Trail Songs is the fifth studio album by Marty Robbins, released on the Columbia Records label in September 1959 and peaking at number six on the U.S. pop albums chart.

title: The Genius of Ray Charles
description: The discography of American musician Ray Charles consists of 54 studio albums, 7 live albums, 39 compilations albums, and 127 singles

title: A Date with the Everly Brothers
description: The Allman Brothers Band was an American rock band formed in Jacksonville, Florida, in 1969. The eponymous brothers Duane and Gregg Allman founded it with Dickey Betts, Berry Oakley (bass), Butch Trucks (drums), and Jai Johanny "Jaimoe" Johanson (drums).

title: Elvis is Back!
description: Elvis Presley is the debut studio album by American rock and roll singer Elvis Presley. It was released by RCA Victor, on March 23, 1956.

title: Joan Baez
description: Joan Baez, also known as Joan Baez, Vol. 1, is the debut solo album by folk singer Joan Baez.

title: Miriam Makeba
description: Miriam Makeba is the debut album by Miriam Makeba. It was released in 1960 by RCA Victor.

title: Muddy Waters at Newport
description: Muddy Waters (1913–1983) was an American blues artist who is considered a pioneer of the electric Chicago blues and a major influence on the development of blues and rock music. He popularized several early Delta blues songs, such as "Rollin' and Tumblin'", "Walkin' Blues", and "Baby, Please Don't Go", and recorded songs that went on to become blues standards, including "Hoochie Coochie Man", "Man

title: Sunday at the Village Vanguard
description: Sunday at the Village Vanguard is a live album by jazz pianist and composer Bill Evans and his Trio consisting of Evans, bassist Scott LaFaro, and drummer Paul Motian. Released in 1961, the album is routinely ranked as one of the best live jazz recordings of all time.

title: Back at the Chicken Shack
description: Back at the Chicken Shack is an album by Jimmy Smith. It was recorded in 1960 and released in 1963 on the Blue Note label.

title: Green Onions
description: Green Onions is the debut album by Booker T. & the M.G.'s, released on Stax Records in October 1962.

title: Modern Sounds In Country And Western Music
description: Modern Sounds in Country and Western Music is a studio album by the American singer and pianist Ray Charles. It was recorded in February 1962 at Capitol Studios in New York City and United Western Recorders in Hollywood, and released in March of that year by ABC-Paramount Records.

title: Jazz Samba
description: Jazz Samba is a bossa nova album by Stan Getz and Charlie Byrd, released by Verve Records in 1962. Jazz Samba signaled the beginning of the bossa nova craze in America.

title: The Black Saint and the Sinner Lady
description: The Black Saint and the Sinner Lady is a studio album by Charles Mingus. It was recorded on January 20, 1963, and released in July of that year by Impulse!

title: Live at the Apollo
description: Live at the Apollo is the first live album by James Brown and the Famous Flames, recorded at the Apollo Theater in Harlem in October 1962 and released in May 1963 by King Records. Capturing Brown's popular stage show for the first time on record, the album was a major commercial success, was critically acclaimed, and cemented his status as a leading R&B star.

title: A Christmas Gift To You
description: A Christmas Gift for You from Phil Spector is a multi-artist studio album of Christmas songs, produced by Phil Spector, originally released by Philles in November 1963. Spector treated a series of mostly secular Christmas standards to his Wall of Sound production style, and the selections feature the vocal performances of Spector's regular artists during this period.

title: Night Life
description: Night Life is the sixth album by country music singer and guitarist Ray Price, backed by his regular touring band, the Cherokee Cowboys. The album was released in 1963 on the Columbia Records label.

title: Live At The Harlem Square Club
description: Live at the Harlem Square Club, 1963 is the second live album by the American singer-songwriter Sam Cooke. The album was recorded at the Harlem Square Club in Miami and released in June 1985 in the United States by RCA Records.

title: With The Beatles
description: The Beatles Anthology is a multimedia retrospective project consisting of a television documentary, a four-volume set of double albums, and a book describing the history of the Beatles. Beatles members Paul McCartney, George Harrison and Ringo Starr participated in the making of the works, which are sometimes referred to collectively as the Anthology project, while John Lennon appears in archival

title: Bert Jansch
description: Bert Jansch is the debut album by Scottish folk musician Bert Jansch. The album was recorded on a reel-to-reel tape recorder at engineer Bill Leader's house and sold to Transatlantic Records for £100.

title: The Freewheelin_ Bob Dylan
description: Bob Dylan is the debut studio album by the American singer-songwriter Bob Dylan, released on March 19, 1962, by Columbia Records. The album was produced by Columbia talent scout John H.

title: A Girl Called Dusty
description: The discography of English pop singer Dusty Springfield includes 21 studio albums, one live album, 30 compilations, four extended plays, and 69 singles. Some of her albums and singles were unreleased, most notably 1974's Longing.

title: Olympia _64
description: Jacques Brel's career spanned over three decades and encompassed a number of singles, EPs, 10" albums and 12" LPs. His songs were often repackaged and resold under different covers and titles, which makes compiling a complete collection of Brel's recordings a difficult task.

title: Rock & Soul
description: Solomon Vincent McDonald Burke was an American singer who shaped the sound of rhythm and blues as one of the founding fathers of soul music in the 1960s. He has been called "a key transitional figure bridging R&B and soul", and was known for his "prodigious output".

title: Getz/Gilberto
description: Getz/Gilberto is an album by American saxophonist Stan Getz and Brazilian guitarist João Gilberto, featuring pianist and composer Antônio Carlos Jobim, who also composed many of the tracks. It was released in March 1964 by Verve Records.

title: The Rolling Stones
description: The Rolling Stones is the debut studio album by the English rock band the Rolling Stones, released by Decca Records in the UK on 17 April 1964. The American edition of the LP, with a slightly different track list, came out on London Records on 29 May 1964, subtitled England's Newest Hit Makers.

title: Live At The Regal
description: Live at the Regal is a 1965 live album by American blues guitarist and singer B.B. King.

title: Bringing It All Back Home
description: Bringing It All Back Home is the fifth studio album by the American singer-songwriter Bob Dylan, released in April 1965 by Columbia Records. Dylan's first album to incorporate electric instrumentation, it was so different from his earlier work that it caused controversy and divided the contemporary folk scene.

title: Highway 61 Revisited
description: Highway 61 Revisited is the sixth studio album by the American singer-songwriter Bob Dylan, released on August 30, 1965, by Columbia Records. Dylan continued the musical approach of his previous album Bringing It All Back Home (1965), using rock musicians as his backing band on every track of the album in a further departure from his primarily acoustic folk sound, except for the closing track, the

title: I_ve Got A Tiger By The Tail
Live At The Star Club, Hamburg
description: Live at the Star Club, Hamburg is a live album by American rock and roll pioneer Jerry Lee Lewis, accompanied by the Nashville Teens. The album was recorded at the Star-Club in Hamburg, West Germany on April 5, 1964.

title: Otis Blue
description: Otis Blue/Otis Redding Sings Soul is the third studio album by the American soul singer and songwriter Otis Redding. It was first released on September 15, 1965, as an LP record through the Stax Records subsidiary label Volt.

title: Today!
description: The Beach Boys Today! is the eighth studio album by the American rock band the Beach Boys, released March 8, 1965, by Capitol Records.

title: Mr Tambourine Man
description: The Byrds were an American rock band formed in Los Angeles, California, in 1964. The band underwent multiple lineup changes; frontman Roger McGuinn was the sole consistent member.

title: Here Are The Sonics
description: Here Are the Sonics is the debut album by American garage rock band the Sonics, released in March 1965. The album features the original songs "The Witch", "Psycho", "Boss Hoss" and "Strychnine", along with an assortment of rock and roll and R&B covers.

title: My Generation
description: My Generation is the debut studio album by the English rock band the Who, released on 3 December 1965 by Brunswick Records in the United Kingdom, and Festival Records in Australia. In the United States, it was released on 25 April 1966 by Decca Records as The Who Sings My Generation, with a different cover and a slightly altered track listing.

title: Blonde On Blonde
description: Blonde on Blonde is the seventh studio album by the American singer-songwriter Bob Dylan, released as a double album on June 20, 1966, by Columbia Records. Recording sessions began in New York in October 1965 with numerous backing musicians, including members of Dylan's live backing band, the Hawks.

title: Sunshine Superman
description: Sunshine Superman is the third studio album by Scottish singer-songwriter Donovan. It was released in the United States on 26 August 1966, but was not released in the UK because of a contractual dispute.

title: Freak Out!
artist: Frank Zappa and the Mothers of Invention
description: Freak Out! is the debut studio album by American rock band the Mothers of Invention, released on June 27, 1966, by Verve Records.

title: Fred Neil
description: Fred Neil is the second album from Fred Neil, a pioneer folk rock musician, recorded and released in 1966. The album has a more laid-back sound than his debut, and contains his best-known songs; "Everybody's Talkin'" and "The Dolphins".

title: Bluesbreakers with Eric Clapton
description: John Brumwell Mayall was an English blues and rock musician, songwriter and producer. In the 1960s, he formed John Mayall & the Bluesbreakers, a band that has counted among its members some of the most famous blues and blues rock musicians of all-time.

title: Mamas And The Papas
description: The Mamas & the Papas were a vocal group from Los Angeles, California, that was active from 1966 to 1969. Their discography consists of a total of five albums and 17 singles, six of which made the Billboard top ten, and sold close to 40 million records worldwide.

title: Wild is the Wind
description: Wild Is the Wind is the sixth studio album by American singer and pianist Nina Simone released by Philips Records in 1966. The album was compiled from several recordings that were left over from sessions for previous Philips albums.

title: Midnight Ride
description: Midnight Ride is the fifth studio album by American rock band Paul Revere & the Raiders. The album featured the U.S.

title: Parsley, Sage, Rosemary and Thyme
description: Parsley, Sage, Rosemary and Thyme is the third studio album by the American folk rock duo Simon & Garfunkel. Produced by Bob Johnston, the album was released on October 24, 1966, in the United States by Columbia Records.

title: The Psychedelic Sounds of the 13th Floor Elevators
description: The Psychedelic Sounds of the 13th Floor Elevators is the debut studio album by the American psychedelic rock band the 13th Floor Elevators. The album showcases the earliest known use of the word "psychedelic" on an album title.

title: Fifth Dimension
description: Fifth Dimension is the third studio album by the American rock band the Byrds, released on July 18, 1966, by Columbia Records. Most of the album was recorded following the February 1966 departure of the band's principal songwriter Gene Clark.

title: Face to Face
description: Face to Face is the fourth studio album by the English rock band the Kinks, released on 28 October 1966. The album marked a shift from the hard-driving style of beat music that had catapulted the group to international acclaim in 1964, instead drawing heavily from baroque pop and music hall.

title: Black Monk Time
description: Black Monk Time is the only studio album by German-based American garage rock band the Monks, released in March 1966 through Polydor Records. It was later retrospectively recognized by music critics as a forerunner to punk rock.

title: Aftermath
description: Aftermath is the fourth studio album by the English rock band the Rolling Stones. The group recorded the album at RCA Studios in California in December 1965 and March 1966, during breaks between their international tours.

title: Yardbirds
description: Roger the Engineer is the only UK studio album and the third US album by the English rock band the Yardbirds. Recorded and released in 1966, it contains all original material and is the only Yardbirds album with guitarist Jeff Beck on all tracks.

title: I Never Loved a Man the Way That I Love You
description: Aretha Louise Franklin was an American singer, songwriter and pianist. Honored as the "Queen of Soul", she was twice named by Rolling Stone magazine as the greatest singer of all time.

title: Buffalo Springfield Again
description: Buffalo Springfield was a Canadian-American rock band formed in Los Angeles in 1966 by Canadians Neil Young, Bruce Palmer and Dewey Martin and Americans Stephen Stills and Richie Furay. The group, widely known for the song "For What It's Worth", released three albums and several singles from 1966 to 1968.

title: Safe As Milk
artist: Captain Beefheart and His Magic Band
description: Safe as Milk is the debut studio album by American music group Captain Beefheart and His Magic Band, released in August 1967 by Buddah Records. A heavily blues-influenced work, the album features a 20-year-old Ry Cooder, who played guitar and wrote some of the arrangements.

title: Electric Music For The Mind And Body
description: Electric Music for the Mind and Body is the debut album by the American psychedelic rock band Country Joe and the Fish. Released in May 1967 on the Vanguard label, it was one of the first psychedelic albums to come out of the San Francisco Bay Area.

title: Disraeli Gears
description: Disraeli Gears is the second studio album by the British rock band Cream. It was produced by Felix Pappalardi and released on Reaction Records in 1967.

title: Francis Albert Sinatra & Antonio Carlos Jobim
artist: Francis Albert Sinatra & Antonio Carlos Jobim
description: Francis Albert Sinatra & Antonio Carlos Jobim is a 1967 album by Frank Sinatra and Antônio Carlos Jobim. The tracks were arranged and conducted by Claus Ogerman, accompanied by a studio orchestra.

title: Surrealistic Pillow
description: Surrealistic Pillow is the second studio album by the American rock band Jefferson Airplane, released on February 1, 1967, by RCA Victor. It is the first album by the band with vocalist Grace Slick and drummer Spencer Dryden.

title: Don't Come Home A-Drinkin_
description: The discography of American country music singer-songwriter Loretta Lynn includes 50 studio albums, 36 compilation albums, two live albums, seven video albums, two box sets and 27 additional album appearances. Briefly recording with the Zero label, she signed an official recording contract with Decca Records in 1961, remaining there for over 20 years The first under the label was her debut studio

title: Da Capo
description: Da Capo is the second studio album by American rock band Love, released in November 1966 by Elektra Records. The album was recorded during September and October 1966 at RCA Studios in Hollywood, California, with the exception of lead single "7 and 7 Is", recorded the previous June.

title: I_m A Lonesome Fugitive
description: Merle Ronald Haggard was an American country music singer, songwriter, guitarist, and fiddler. Widely regarded as one of the greatest and most influential figures in country music, he was a central pioneer of the Bakersfield sound.

title: Moby Grape
description: Moby Grape is the 1967 debut studio album by rock band Moby Grape. Coming from the San Francisco scene, their reputation quickly grew to immense proportions, leading to a bidding war and a contract with Columbia Records.

title: Chelsea Girl
description: Chelsea Girl is the debut solo album by the German singer Nico, produced by Tom Wilson. It was released in October 1967 by Verve Records and was recorded following Nico's collaboration with the Velvet Underground on their 1967 debut studio album.

title: The Piper at the Gates of Dawn
description: The Piper at the Gates of Dawn is the debut studio album by the English rock band Pink Floyd, released on 4 August 1967 by EMI Columbia. It is the only Pink Floyd album recorded under the leadership of founder member Syd Barrett ; he was the sole writer of all but three tracks, with additional writing by members Roger Waters, Nick Mason (drums), and Richard Wright.

title: Sgt Pepper_s Lonely Hearts Club Band
Triangle
description: Triangle is the fourth studio album by American rock band the Beau Brummels. Produced by Lenny Waronker and released in July 1967, it was the band's first album to include songs that vocalist Sal Valentino and guitarist Ron Elliott composed together.

title: Younger Than Yesterday
description: Younger Than Yesterday is the fourth studio album by the American rock band the Byrds, released on February 6, 1967, by Columbia Records. It saw the band continuing to integrate elements of psychedelia and jazz into their music, a process they had begun on their previous album, Fifth Dimension.

title: I Had Too Much to Dream Last Night
description: The Electric Prunes are an American psychedelic rock band, formed in Los Angeles, California, in 1965. Much of the band's music was, as music historian Richie Unterberger described it, possessed of "an eerie and sometimes anguished ambiance." Their most successful material was by songwriters Annette Tucker and Nancie Mantz, though the group also penned their own songs.

title: Are You Experienced?
description: Are You Experienced is the debut studio album by the Jimi Hendrix Experience, released in May 1967. The album was an immediate critical and commercial success, and is widely regarded as one of the greatest albums of all time.

title: Axis: Bold As Love
description: Axis: Bold as Love is the second studio album by the Jimi Hendrix Experience. It was first released by Track Records in the United Kingdom on December 1, 1967, only seven months after the release of the group's highly successful debut album, Are You Experienced.

title: Something Else by The Kinks
description: Something Else by the Kinks, often referred to simply as Something Else, is the fifth studio album by the English rock band the Kinks, released on 15 September 1967 by Pye Records. The album continued the Kinks' trend toward an eccentric baroque pop and music hall-influenced style defined by frontman Ray Davies' observational and introspective lyrics.

title: Headquarters
description: Headquarters is the third studio album by the American pop rock band The Monkees, released on May 22, 1967, by Colgems Records. It was the first Monkees album on which the four band members played instruments and wrote much of the material themselves, following a struggle for creative control over their music with supervisor Don Kirshner.

title: We_re Only in it for the Money
description: The Mothers of Invention was an American rock band from California. Formed on May 9, 1965, their work is marked by the use of sonic experimentation, innovative album art, and elaborate live shows.

title: White Light/White Heat
description: White Light/White Heat is the second studio album by the American rock band the Velvet Underground. Released on January 30, 1968, by Verve Records, it was the band's last studio album with multi-instrumentalist and founding member John Cale.

title: The Who Sell Out
description: The Who Sell Out is the third studio album by the English rock band the Who. It was released on 15 December 1967 by Track Records in the UK and Decca Records in the US.

title: Groovin_
description: Groovin' is the third album by the rock band the Young Rascals. The album was released on July 31, 1967 and rose to #5 on the Billboard Top LPs chart, number 7 on the R&B chart, and number 2 in Canada.

title: Goodbye And Hello
description: Goodbye and Hello is the second album by Tim Buckley, released in 1967. It was recorded in Los Angeles, California, in June of the same year.

title: Oar
description: Oar is the only studio album by American singer-songwriter Alexander "Skip" Spence, released on May 19, 1969, by Columbia Records. It was recorded over seven days in December 1968 in Nashville, and features Spence on all of the instruments.

title: Aretha: Lady Soul
description: Aretha is the thirty-first studio album by American singer Aretha Franklin, released on October 27, 1986, by Arista Records. It is the third album with the Aretha title to be released by Franklin, following her 1961 album and 1980 album.

title: Beach Samba
description: Astrud Gilberto was a Brazilian and American bossa nova and samba singer. She was the first wife of Brazilian bossa nova guitarist João Gilberto, whose surname she continued to use professionally after their divorce in 1964.

title: Cheap Thrills
artist: Big Brother and the Holding Company
description: Cheap Thrills is the second studio album by American rock band Big Brother and the Holding Company, released on August 12, 1968, by Columbia Records. Cheap Thrills was the band's final album with lead singer Janis Joplin before she left to begin a solo career.

title: Vincebus Eruptum
description: Vincebus Eruptum is the debut album of American rock band Blue Cheer. Released on January 16, 1968, the album features a heavy-thunderous blues sound, which would later be known as heavy metal.

title: Caetano Veloso
description: Caetano Emanuel Viana Teles Veloso is a Brazilian singer-songwriter, musician and political activist. Veloso first became known for his participation in the Brazilian musical movement Tropicália, which encompassed theatre, poetry and music in the 1960s, at the beginning of the Brazilian military dictatorship that took power in 1964.

title: In-a-gadda-da-vida
description: In-A-Gadda-Da-Vida is the second studio album by the American rock band Iron Butterfly, released in June 1968. It is most known for its title track, a 17-minute composition that occupies the entirety of Side B.

title: Truth
description: Truth is the debut studio album by English guitarist Jeff Beck, released on 29 July 1968 in the United States on Epic Records and on 4 October 1968 in the United Kingdom on Columbia Records. It introduced the talents of his backing band the Jeff Beck Group, specifically vocalist Rod Stewart and bassist/guitarist Ronnie Wood, to a larger audience, and peaked at number 15 on the Billboard Top LPs ch

title: Johnny Cash at Folsom Prison
description: The albums discography of American singer Johnny Cash spans his lengthy career, from 1954 to 2003. It includes the release of 130 albums, most of them for Columbia Records.

title: Eli And The Thirteenth Confession
description: Eli and the Thirteenth Confession is the second album by New York City-born singer, songwriter and pianist Laura Nyro, released in 1968.

title: Songs Of Leonard Cohen
description: Songs of Leonard Cohen is the debut studio album by Canadian singer-songwriter Leonard Cohen, released on December 27, 1967, on Columbia Records. More successful in Europe than in North America, Songs of Leonard Cohen foreshadowed the kind of chart success Cohen would go on to achieve.

title: Os Mutantes
description: Os Mutantes is the debut album by the Brazilian tropicalia band Os Mutantes. It was originally released in 1968 by Polydor and blends traditional Brazilian music styles with American and British psychedelia.

title: The Sounds of India
description: The Sounds of India is an album by Ravi Shankar which introduces and explains Hindustani classical music to Western audiences. Released by Columbia Records in 1957, it was influenced by Ali Akbar Khan's The Sounds of India, and recorded and produced by George Avakian in 1957 at Columbia's New York studio.

title: Scott 2
description: Noel Scott Engel, better known by his stage name Scott Walker, was an American-British singer-songwriter and record producer who resided in England. Walker was known for his emotive voice and his unorthodox stylistic path which took him from being a teen pop icon in the 1960s to an avant-garde musician from the 1990s to his death.

title: Bookends
description: Bookends is the fourth studio album by the American folk rock duo Simon & Garfunkel. Produced by Paul Simon, Art Garfunkel and Roy Halee, the album was released on April 3, 1968, in the United States by Columbia Records.

title: Music from Big Pink
description: Music from Big Pink is the debut studio album by the Canadian-American rock band the Band. Released on July 1, 1968, by Capitol Records, it employs a distinctive blend of country, rock, folk, classical, R&B, blues, and soul.

title: The Beatles (White Album)
description: Worldwide, the English rock band the Beatles have released 12 studio albums, 5 live albums, 52 compilation albums, 36 extended plays (EPs), and 37 box sets. Their output also includes vault items, remixed mash-ups and anniversary box-sets.

title: The Notorious Byrd Brothers
description: The Notorious Byrd Brothers is the fifth studio album by the American rock band the Byrds, released on January 15, 1968, by Columbia Records. The album represents the pinnacle of the Byrds' late-'60s musical experimentation, with the band blending together elements of psychedelia, folk rock, country, electronic music, baroque pop, and jazz.

title: Sweetheart Of The Rodeo
description: Sweetheart of the Rodeo is the sixth studio album by the American rock band the Byrds, released in August 1968 by Columbia Records. Recorded with the addition of country rock pioneer Gram Parsons, it became the first album widely recognized as country rock as well as a seminal progressive country album, and represented a stylistic move away from the psychedelic rock of the band's previous LP, The

title: The Hangman_s Beautiful Daughter
description: The Incredible String Band is the debut album by The Incredible String Band, released in the United Kingdom in October 1966 by record label Elektra. It is the only one of the band's albums to feature the original trio line-up with Clive Palmer, Robin Williamson and Mike Heron.

title: Village Green Preservation Society
description: The Kinks Are the Village Green Preservation Society is the sixth studio album by the English rock band the Kinks. Released on 22 November 1968, Village Green was a modest seller, but it was lauded by contemporary critics for its songwriting and has subsequently been regarded by commentators as an early concept album.

title: SF Sorrow
description: The Pretty Things were an English rock band formed in September 1963 in Sidcup, Kent, taking their name from Bo Diddley's 1955 song "Pretty Thing", and active in their first incarnation until 1971. They released five studio albums, including the debut The Pretty Things and S.

title: Beggars Banquet
description: Beggars Banquet is the seventh studio album by the English rock band the Rolling Stones, released on 6 December 1968 by Decca Records in the United Kingdom and London Records in the United States. It was the first Rolling Stones album produced by Jimmy Miller, whose production work formed a key aspect of the Rolling Stones' sound throughout the late 1960s and early 1970s.

title: The United States Of America
description: The Presidents of the United States of America is the self-titled debut studio album by the American alternative rock band The Presidents of the United States of America, released on March 10, 1995, via PopLlama Records. Columbia Records signed the band shortly after its release to handle increased distribution for the album.

title: Tommy
description: Tommy is the fourth studio album by the English rock band the Who, released on 19 May 1969. Written primarily by guitarist Pete Townshend, Tommy is a double album and an early rock opera that tells the story of the fictional Tommy Walker and his path to becoming a spiritual leader and messianic figure.

title: Odessey And Oracle
description: Odessey and Oracle is the second studio album by the English rock band the Zombies. It was released on 19 April 1968, by CBS Records in the UK and on 15 July 1968, by Date Records in the US.

title: Happy Sad
description: Happy Sad is the third album by American singer-songwriter Tim Buckley, released in April 1969. It was recorded at Elektra Sound Recorders in Los Angeles, California and was produced by former Lovin' Spoonful members Zal Yanovsky and, coincidentally, his subsequent replacement Jerry Yester.

title: Traffic
description: Traffic is the second studio album by the English rock band of the same name, released on 20 September 1968 on Island Records in the United Kingdom as ILPS 9081T (stereo), and United Artists in the United States, as UAS 6676 (stereo). The album peaked at number 9 in the UK Albums Chart and at number 17 on the Billboard Top LPs chart.

title: Blood, Sweat And Tears
description: Blood, Sweat & Tears is the second album by the American band Blood, Sweat & Tears, released on December 11, 1968. It was the most commercially successful album for the group, rising to the top of the U.S.

title: Trout Mask Replica
artist: Captain Beefheart and His Magic Band
description: Trout Mask Replica is the third studio album by the American band Captain Beefheart and His Magic Band, released as a double album on June 16, 1969, by Straight Records. The music was composed by Captain Beefheart and arranged by drummer John "Drumbo" French.

title: Chicago Transit Authority
description: The Chicago Transit Authority is the debut studio album by the American rock band Chicago, and the only album released under their original name Chicago Transit Authority. The double album was released on April 28, 1969, and became a sleeper hit, reaching number 17 on the Billboard 200 by 1971.

title: Bayou Country
description: Bayou Country is the second studio album by the American rock band Creedence Clearwater Revival (CCR), released by Fantasy Records on January 15, 1969, and was the first of three albums CCR released in that year. Bayou Country reached No.

title: Green River
description: Green River is the third studio album by the American rock band Creedence Clearwater Revival, released on August 7, 1969, by Fantasy Records. It was the second of three albums they released in that year, preceded by Bayou Country in January and followed by Willy and the Poor Boys in October.

title: Crosby, Stills And Nash
description: Crosby, Stills & Nash is the debut studio album by the folk rock supergroup Crosby, Stills & Nash (CSN), released on May 29, 1969, by Atlantic Records. It is the only release by the band prior to adding Neil Young to their lineup.

title: Gris Gris
description: Malcolm John Rebennack Jr., better known by his stage name Dr. John, was an American singer, songwriter and pianist.

title: Dusty in Memphis
description: The discography of English pop singer Dusty Springfield includes 21 studio albums, one live album, 30 compilations, four extended plays, and 69 singles. Some of her albums and singles were unreleased, most notably 1974's Longing.

title: From Elvis in Memphis
description: The albums discography of Elvis Presley began in 1956 with the release of his debut album, Elvis Presley.

title: Liege And Lief
description: Full House is a 1970 album by British folk rock group Fairport Convention, their fifth since their debut, Fairport Convention in 1968, and their first without a female vocalist.

title: Unhalfbricking
description: Unhalfbricking is the third studio album by the English folk rock band Fairport Convention and the first of two albums released by the band in 1969. It is seen as a transitional album in their history and marked a further musical move away from American influences towards more traditional English folk songs that had begun on their previous album, What We Did on Our Holidays and reached its peak on

title: Hot Rats
description: Hot Rats is the second solo album and eighth overall album by Frank Zappa, released in October 1969. It was Zappa's first recording project after the dissolution of the original lineup of the Mothers of Invention.

title: Hot Buttered Soul
description: Hot Buttered Soul is the second studio album by American soul musician Isaac Hayes. Released in June 1969, it is recognized as a landmark recording in soul music.

title: Johnny Cash at San Quentin
description: The albums discography of American singer Johnny Cash spans his lengthy career, from 1954 to 2003. It includes the release of 130 albums, most of them for Columbia Records.

title: In The Court of the Crimson King
description: In the Court of the Crimson King is the debut studio album by English progressive rock band King Crimson, released on 10 October 1969, by Island Records. Often regarded as the first true progressive rock album, it combined rock music influences with elements of jazz, classical, and symphonic music while describing the devastating effects of war and conflict, societal alienation and disillusionment

title: Led Zeppelin I
description: Led Zeppelin II is the second studio album by the English rock band Led Zeppelin, released on 22 October 1969 in the United States and on 31 October 1969 in the United Kingdom by Atlantic Records. Recording sessions for the album took place at several locations in both the United Kingdom and North America from January to August 1969.

title: Songs From A Room
description: Songs of Leonard Cohen is the debut studio album by Canadian singer-songwriter Leonard Cohen, released on December 27, 1967, on Columbia Records. More successful in Europe than in North America, Songs of Leonard Cohen foreshadowed the kind of chart success Cohen would go on to achieve.

title: In A Silent Way
description: In a Silent Way is a studio album by the American jazz trumpeter, composer, and bandleader Miles Davis, released on July 30, 1969, on Columbia Records. Produced by Teo Macero, the album was recorded in one session date on February 18, 1969, at CBS 30th Street Studio in New York City.

title: Everybody Knows This Is Nowhere
description: Everybody Knows This Is Nowhere is the second studio album by Canadian-American musician Neil Young, released in May 1969 on Reprise Records, catalogue number RS 6349. His first with longtime backing band Crazy Horse, it emerged as a sleeper hit amid Young's contemporaneous success with Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young, ultimately peaking at number 34 on the US Billboard 200 in August 1970 during a 98

title: Five Leaves Left
description: Five Leaves Left is the debut studio album by English folk musician Nick Drake. Recorded between 1968 and 1969, it was released in 1969 by Island Records.

title: Basket Of Light
description: Basket of Light is a 1969 album by the British folk rock group Pentangle. It reached no.

title: Happy Trails
description: Happy Trails is the second album of the American band Quicksilver Messenger Service. Most of the album was recorded from two performances at the Fillmore East and Fillmore West, although it is not clear which parts were recorded at which Fillmore.

title: Scott 4
description: Noel Scott Engel, better known by his stage name Scott Walker, was an American-British singer-songwriter and record producer who resided in England. Walker was known for his emotive voice and his unorthodox stylistic path which took him from being a teen pop icon in the 1960s to an avant-garde musician from the 1990s to his death.

title: Stand!
description: Stand! is the fourth album by American soul-funk band Sly and the Family Stone, released on May 3, 1969.

title: The Band
description: The Band, also known as The Brown Album, is the second studio album by the Canadian-American rock band the Band, released on September 22, 1969, by Capitol Records. According to Rob Bowman's liner notes for the 2000 reissue, The Band has been viewed as a concept album, with the songs focusing on people, places and traditions associated with a traditional view of Americana.

title: Odessa
description: Odessa is the sixth studio album by the Bee Gees, a double vinyl LP released in February 1969 in the US and March 1969 in the UK, initially in an opulent red flocked cover with gold lettering. Despite reaching the UK top ten and the US top 20, the album was not particularly well-received, though now is regarded by many as the most significant of the group's 1960s albums.

title: The Gilded Palace of Sin
description: The Gilded Palace of Sin is the debut studio album by American country rock band The Flying Burrito Brothers, released on February 6, 1969, by A&M Records. It continued Gram Parsons' and Chris Hillman's work in modern country music, fusing traditional styles such as folk and country with other forms of popular music including gospel, soul, and psychedelic rock.

title: Arthur, or the Decline and Fall of the British Empire
description: Arthur (Or the Decline and Fall of the British Empire), often referred to simply as Arthur, is the seventh studio album by the English rock band the Kinks, released on 10 October 1969. It was the first Kinks album to feature bassist John Dalton, who replaced Pete Quaife after the latter's departure.

title: Kick Out The Jams
description: "Kick Out the Jams" is a song by American rock band MC5, released as a single in March 1969 by Elektra Records. The album of the same name caused some controversy due to inflammatory liner notes by the band's manager, John Sinclair, and the track's rallying cry of "Kick out the jams, motherfuckers!".

title: Let It Bleed
description: Let It Bleed is the eighth studio album by the English rock band the Rolling Stones, released on 28 November 1969 by London Records in the United States and on 5 December 1969 by Decca Records in the United Kingdom. Released during the band's 1969 American Tour, it is the follow-up to Beggars Banquet (1968), and, like that album, is a return to the group's more blues-oriented approach that was pro

title: The Stooges
description: The Stooges is the debut studio album by American rock band the Stooges, released on August 5, 1969, by Elektra Records. Considered a landmark proto-punk release, the album peaked at number 106 on the US Billboard Top 200 Albums chart.

title: Cloud Nine
description: Cloud Nine is the ninth studio album by American musical group The Temptations for the Gordy (Motown) label released in 1969.

title: The Velvet Underground
description: The Velvet Underground is the third studio album by the American rock band the Velvet Underground. Released in March 1969 by MGM Records, it was their first record with multi-instrumentalist Doug Yule, who replaced previous member John Cale.

title: Elephant Mountain
description: Elephant Mountain is the third studio album by the American rock band The Youngbloods, released in 1969. It reached number 118 on the Billboard 200 chart.

title: Ananda Shankar
description: Ananda Shankar is the debut album by the Indian musician Ananda Shankar, the son of dancer and choreographer Uday Shankar and the nephew of the Indian classical musician Ravi Shankar. It was released in 1970 on the Reprise record label.

title: Black Sabbath
description: Black Sabbath is the debut studio album by the English heavy metal band Black Sabbath, released on 13 February 1970 by Vertigo Records in the United Kingdom and on 1 June 1970 by Warner Bros. Records in the United States.

title: Paranoid
description: Paranoid is the second studio album by the British heavy metal band Black Sabbath. It was released on 18 September 1970 in the United Kingdom by Vertigo Records, and on 7 January 1971 in the United States by Warner Bros.

title: Tea for the Tillerman
description: Tea for the Tillerman is the fourth studio album by singer-songwriter Cat Stevens, released in November 1970.

title: Deep Purple in Rock
description: Deep Purple in Rock is the fourth studio album by English rock band Deep Purple, released on 5 June 1970. It was the first studio album recorded by the Mark II line-up of Ritchie Blackmore, Ian Gillan, Roger Glover, Jon Lord and Ian Paice.

title: All Things Must Pass
description: All Things Must Pass is the third studio album by the English musician George Harrison. Released as a triple album on 27 November 1970, it was Harrison's first solo work after the break-up of the Beatles in April that year.

title: Fun House
description: Fun House is the second studio album by American rock band the Stooges. It was released on July 7, 1970, by Elektra Records.

title: Sweet Baby James
description: Sweet Baby James is the second studio album by American singer-songwriter James Taylor, released on February 1, 1970, by Warner Bros. Records.

title: John Lennon/Plastic Ono Band
description: John Lennon was an English musician, best known as the co-founder, co-lead vocalist and rhythm guitarist of the Beatles. After three experimental albums with Yoko Ono, using tape loops, interviews, musique concrète, and other avant-garde performance techniques, Lennon's solo career properly began with the 1969 single "Give Peace a Chance".

title: Led Zeppelin III
description: Led Zeppelin III is the third studio album by the English rock band Led Zeppelin, released on 5 October 1970. It was recorded in three locations.

title: McCartney
description: McCartney is the debut solo studio album by the English rock musician Paul McCartney, released on 17 April 1970 by Apple Records. McCartney recorded it in secrecy, mostly using basic home-recording equipment at his house in St John's Wood.

title: Bryter Later
description: Nicholas Rodney Drake was an English singer-songwriter. An accomplished acoustic guitarist, Drake signed to Island Records at the age of twenty while still a student at the University of Cambridge.

title: Gasoline Alley
description: Gasoline Alley is the second solo studio album by the British singer-songwriter Rod Stewart. It was released on 12 June 1970 by Vertigo Records.

title: Abraxas
description: Abraxas is the second studio album by the American rock band Santana. It was released on September 23, 1970, by Columbia Records and became the band's first album to top the Billboard 200 in the United States.

title: Bridge Over Troubled Water
description: Bridge Over Troubled Water is the fifth and final studio album by American folk rock duo Simon & Garfunkel. The album was released on January 26, 1970, through Columbia Records.

title: Third
description: Third is the third studio album by the English rock band Soft Machine, released in June 1970 by CBS Records in the United Kingdom and Columbia Records in the United States. The album was recorded from January to May 1970, partially at IBC Studios, based in London, and was produced by the band themselves.

title: Stephen Stills
description: Stephen Stills is the debut solo album by American musician Stephen Stills released on Atlantic Records in 1970. It is one of four high-profile albums released by each member of Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young in the wake of their 1970 chart-topping album Déjà Vu, along with After the Gold Rush, If I Could Only Remember My Name and Songs for Beginners.

title: The Madcap Laughs
description: The Madcap Laughs is the debut solo album by the English singer-songwriter Syd Barrett. It was recorded after Barrett had left Pink Floyd in April 1968.

title: Close To You
description: Close to You is the second studio album by the American music duo the Carpenters, released on August 19, 1970. In 2003, the album was ranked No.

title: Morrison Hotel
description: Morrison Hotel is the fifth studio album by American rock band the Doors, released on February 9, 1970, by Elektra Records. After the use of brass and string arrangements recommended by producer Paul A.

title: American Beauty
description: American Beauty is the fifth studio album by American rock band the Grateful Dead. Released in November 1970, by Warner Bros.

title: Live/Dead
description: In the Dark is the twelfth studio album by American rock band the Grateful Dead. It was released on July 6, 1987, by Arista Records.

title: Live at Leeds
description: Live at Leeds is the first live album by the English rock band the Who, recorded at the University of Leeds Refectory on 14 February 1970 and released on 11 May 1970, by Decca and MCA in the United States and by Track and Polydor in the United Kingdom. It is the band's only live album that was recorded with the classic line-up of lead vocalist Roger Daltrey, guitarist Pete Townshend, bassist John

title: John Barleycorn Must Die
description: John Barleycorn Must Die is the fourth studio album by English rock band Traffic, released in 1970 as Island ILPS 9116 in the United Kingdom, United Artists UAS 5504 in the United States, and as Polydor 2334 013 in Canada. It marked the band's comeback after a brief disbandment, and peaked at number 5 on the Billboard Top LPs chart, making it their highest-charting album in the US, and has been ce

title: Moondance
description: Moondance is the third studio album by Northern Irish singer-songwriter Van Morrison. It was released on 27 January 1970 by Warner Bros.

title: Tago Mago
description: Tago Mago is the second studio album by the German krautrock band Can, originally released as a double LP in August 1971 on United Artists Records. It was the band's first full studio album to feature vocalist Damo Suzuki after the departure of Malcolm Mooney the year prior, though Suzuki had been featured on most tracks on the 1970 compilation album Soundtracks.

title: Tapestry
description: Tapestry is the second studio album by the American singer-songwriter Carole King. Produced by Lou Adler, it was released on February 10, 1971, by Ode Records.

title: Cosmo's Factory
description: Pendulum is the sixth studio album by the American rock band Creedence Clearwater Revival, released by Fantasy Records on December 9, 1970. It was the second studio album the band released that year, arriving five months after Cosmo's Factory.

title: If Only I Could Remember My Name
description: David Crosby: Remember My Name is a 2019 documentary about the musician David Crosby. It was directed by A.J.

title: Coat Of Many Colors
description: Coat of Many Colors is the eighth solo studio album by American singer-songwriter Dolly Parton. It was released on October 4, 1971, by RCA Victor.

title: American Pie
description: American Pie is the second studio album by American singer-songwriter Don McLean, released by United Artists Records in October 1971. The folk rock album reached number one on the Billboard 200, containing the chart-topping singles "American Pie" and "Vincent".

title: Madman Across The Water
description: Madman Across the Water is the fourth studio album by British musician Elton John, released on 5 November 1971 by DJM and Uni Records. The album was his third album to be released in 1971, at which point John had been rising to prominence as a popular music artist.

title: Tarkus
description: Tarkus is the second studio album by English progressive rock band Emerson, Lake & Palmer, released on 4 June 1971 by Island Records. Following their debut tour across Europe during the second half of 1970, the group paused touring commitments in January 1971 to record a new album at Advision Studios in London.

title: Pictures at an Exhibition
description: Pictures at an Exhibition is a live album by English progressive rock band Emerson, Lake & Palmer, released in the United Kingdom in November 1971 by Island Records and in the United States in January 1972 by Cotillion Records. It features the group's adaptation of Pictures at an Exhibition, the piano suite by Modest Mussorgsky, performed at Newcastle City Hall on 26 March 1971.

title: Live With Ginger Baker
description: Live! is a live in-studio album by Fela Kuti's band Africa '70, with the addition of former Cream drummer Ginger Baker on two songs.

title: Maggot Brain
description: Maggot Brain is the third studio album by the American funk rock band Funkadelic, released by Westbound Records in July 1971. It was produced by bandleader George Clinton and recorded at United Sound Systems in Detroit during late 1970 and early 1971.

title: Nilsson Schmilsson
description: Nilsson Schmilsson is the seventh studio album by American singer Harry Nilsson, released by RCA Records on November 11, 1971. It was Nilsson's most commercially successful work, producing three of his best-known songs.

title: Shaft
description: Shaft is a double album by Isaac Hayes, recorded for Stax Records' Enterprise label as the soundtrack LP for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's 1971 blaxploitation film Shaft. The album mostly consists of instrumentals composed by Hayes as score for the film.

title: Pearl
description: Pearl is the second and final solo album by the American singer Janis Joplin, released on January 11, 1971, by Columbia Records. The album was released three months after Joplin's death on October 4, 1970.

title: Aqualung
description: Aqualung is the fourth studio album by the English rock band Jethro Tull, released in March 1971 by Chrysalis Records.

title: Imagine
description: Imagine is the second solo studio album by the English musician John Lennon, released on 9 September 1971 by Apple Records. Co-produced by Lennon, his wife Yoko Ono and Phil Spector, the album's elaborate sound contrasts the basic, small-group arrangements of his first album, John Lennon/Plastic Ono Band (1970).

title: Blue
description: Blue is the fourth studio album by the Canadian singer-songwriter Joni Mitchell, released on June 22, 1971, by Reprise Records. Written and produced by Mitchell, it was recorded in 1971 at A&M Studios in Hollywood, California.

title: Led Zeppelin IV (Four Symbols)
description: The discography of the English rock band Led Zeppelin consists of 9 studio albums, 4 live albums, 10 compilation albums, 19 singles, 16 music videos and 9 music downloads. The band is estimated to have sold over 300 million records worldwide, becoming one of the best-selling music artists in history.

title: Songs of Love and Hate
description: Songs of Love and Hate is the third studio album by Canadian singer-songwriter Leonard Cohen. Produced by Bob Johnston, the album was released on March 19, 1971, through Columbia Records.

title: Every Picture Tells A Story
description: Every Picture Tells a Story is the third studio album by British singer-songwriter Rod Stewart, released on 28 May 1971, by Mercury Records. It incorporates hard rock, folk, and blues styles.

title: Histoire de Melody Nelson
description: Histoire de Melody Nelson is a 1971 concept album by French singer and songwriter Serge Gainsbourg, arranged and co-written by Jean-Claude Vannier. Produced by Jean-Claude Desmarty, the album was released on March 24, 1971 through Philips Records.

title: There_s a Riot Goin_ On
artist: Sly and and The Family Stone
description: Sly and the Family Stone was an American band formed in San Francisco, California, in 1966 and active until 1983. Their work, which blended elements of funk, soul, psychedelic rock, gospel, and R&B, became a pivotal influence on subsequent American popular music.

title: Electric Warrior
description: Electric Warrior is the second studio album by English rock band T. Rex and their sixth since their 1968 debut as Tyrannosaurus Rex, released on 24 September 1971, by Fly Records in the United Kingdom and Reprise Records in the United States.

title: The Allman Brothers at Fillmore East
description: The Allman Brothers Band is the debut studio album by American rock band the Allman Brothers Band. Produced by Adrian Barber, it was released in the United States on November 4, 1969, by Atco Records subsidiary Capricorn.

title: Surf_s Up
description: The Beach Boys are an American rock band formed in Hawthorne, California, in 1961. The group's original lineup consisted of brothers Brian, Dennis, and Carl Wilson, their cousin Mike Love, and their friend Al Jardine.

title: Trafalgar
description: Trafalgar is a 1971 album by the Bee Gees. It was their ninth album, and was released in September 1971 in the US, and November 1971 in the UK.

title: LA Woman
description: The following is the discography of the American rock band the Doors. Formed in Los Angeles in 1965, the group consisted of Jim Morrison (vocals), Ray Manzarek (keyboards), John Densmore (drums), and Robby Krieger (guitar).

title: A Nod_s As Good As Wink
Teenage Head
description: Teenage Head is the third studio album by the San Francisco rock band Flamin' Groovies, released in March 1971 by Kama Sutra Records.

title: Sticky Fingers
description: Sticky Fingers is the ninth studio album by the English rock band the Rolling Stones. It was released on 23 April 1971 on the Rolling Stones' new label, Rolling Stones Records.

title: Who_s Next
description: Tommy is the fourth studio album by the English rock band the Who, released on 19 May 1969. Written primarily by guitarist Pete Townshend, Tommy is a double album and an early rock opera that tells the story of the fictional Tommy Walker and his path to becoming a spiritual leader and messianic figure.

title: The Yes Album
description: The Yes Album is the third studio album by English progressive rock band Yes, released in the UK on 19 February 1971 and in the US on 19 March 1971 by Atlantic Records. It was the band's first album to feature guitarist Steve Howe, who replaced Peter Banks in 1970, as well as their last to feature keyboardist Tony Kaye until 1983's 90125.

title: Fragile
description: Fragile is the fourth studio album by the English progressive rock band Yes, released in the UK on 12 November 1971 and in the US on 4 January 1972 by Atlantic Records. It was the band's first album to feature keyboardist Rick Wakeman, who replaced Tony Kaye after the group had finished touring their breakthrough record, The Yes Album (1971).

title: Let_s Stay Together
description: "Let's Stay Together" is a song by American singer Al Green from his 1972 album of the same name. It was produced and recorded by Willie Mitchell, and mixed by Mitchell and Terry Manning.

title: School_s Out
description: The Revenge of Alice Cooper is the eighth studio album by American rock band Alice Cooper. It was released on July 25, 2025, by earMusic and is the group's first full collaboration since 1973's Muscle of Love.

title: No.1 Record
description: Big Star was an American rock band formed in Memphis, Tennessee in 1971 by Alex Chilton, Chris Bell, Jody Stephens (drums), and Andy Hummel (bass). They have been described as the "quintessential American power pop band", and "one of the most mythic and influential cult acts in all of rock & roll".

title: Volume 4
description: Vol. 4 is the fourth studio album by the English heavy metal band Black Sabbath, released in September 1972, by Vertigo Records.

title: Marcus Garvey
description: Marcus Garvey is the third album by reggae artist Burning Spear, released in 1975 on Fox Records in Jamaica and then internationally on Island Records later in the year. The album is named after the Jamaican National Hero and Rastafari movement prophet Marcus Garvey.

title: Superfly
description: Curtis is the debut studio album by American soul musician Curtis Mayfield, released in September 1970. Produced by Mayfield, it was released on his own label Curtom Records.

title: American Gothic
description: American Gothic is the third studio album by American singer-songwriter David Ackles. It was released on July 4, 1972, by record label Elektra.

title: Ziggy Stardust and the Spiders from Mars
description: Ziggy Stardust and the Spiders from Mars is a 1979 British documentary/concert film by D. A.

title: Hunky Dory
description: Hunky Dory is the fourth studio album by the English musician David Bowie, released in the United Kingdom on 17 December 1971 through RCA Records. Following a break from touring and recording, Bowie settled down to write new songs, composing on piano rather than guitar as in earlier works.

title: Machine Head
description: Machine Head is the sixth studio album by English rock band Deep Purple. It was recorded in December 1971 in Montreux, Switzerland, and released on 30 March 1972, by Purple Records.

title: White Light
description: White Light is the second solo album by Gene Clark, former member of The Byrds. It achieved commercial success only in the Netherlands, where rock critics also voted it album of the year.

title: Home is Where the Music Is
description: Home Is Where the Music Is is a 1972 jazz and Afrobeat double LP by Hugh Masekela issued by the joint American label Chisa/Blue Thumb Records. The album was included in the book 1001 Albums You Must Hear Before You Die.

title: John Prine
description: John Prine is the debut album by American country/folk singer-songwriter John Prine, issued by Atlantic Records in 1971. In 2012, the album was ranked number 452 on Rolling Stone magazine's list of the 500 greatest albums of all time.

title: Transformer
description: Transformer is the second solo studio album by American musician Lou Reed. Produced by David Bowie and Mick Ronson, the album was released on November 8, 1972 by RCA Records.

title: Clube Da Esquina
description: Clube da Esquina is a collaborative album by Brazilian musicians Milton Nascimento and Lô Borges, released as a double album in March 1972 by EMI-Odeon Records. It was Nascimento's fifth studio album and Lô's first, after which the latter pursued a solo career.

title: Harvest
description: Harvest is the fourth studio album by Canadian-American musician Neil Young, released on February 15, 1972, by Reprise Records, catalogue number MS 2032. It featured the London Symphony Orchestra on two tracks and vocals by guests David Crosby, Graham Nash, Linda Ronstadt, Stephen Stills, and James Taylor.

title: Pink Moon
description: Pink Moon is the third and final studio album by the English musician Nick Drake, released in the UK by Island Records on 25 February 1972. It was the only one of Drake's studio albums to be released in North America during his lifetime.

title: Will The Circle Be Unbroken
description: Will the Circle Be Unbroken is the seventh studio album by American country music group the Nitty Gritty Dirt Band, released in November 1972, through United Artists Records. The album was a collaboration with many famous bluegrass and country-and-western players, including Roy Acuff, "Mother" Maybelle Carter, Doc Watson, Earl Scruggs, Randy Scruggs, Merle Travis, Pete "Oswald" Kirby, Norman Blake

title: Paul Simon
description: Paul Simon is the second solo studio album by American singer-songwriter Paul Simon. It was released in January 1972, nearly two years after he split up with longtime musical partner Art Garfunkel.

title: Sail Away
description: Sail Away is the third studio album by Randy Newman, released on May 23, 1972. It was produced by Lenny Waronker and Russ Titelman and issued on Reprise Records.

title: Roxy Music
description: Roxy Music is the debut studio album by the English rock band Roxy Music, released on 16 June 1972 by Island Records.

title: Slayed?
description: Slayed? is the third studio album by the British rock group Slade.

title: Can_t Buy a Thrill
description: Steely Dan is an American rock band formed in Annandale-on-Hudson, New York, in 1971 by Walter Becker and Donald Fagen. Originally having a traditional band lineup, Becker and Fagen chose to stop performing live by the end of 1974 and continued Steely Dan as a studio-only duo, using a revolving cast of session musicians.

title: Talking Book
description: Talking Book is the fifteenth studio album by American singer, songwriter, and musician Stevie Wonder, released on October 27, 1972, by Tamla, a subsidiary of Motown Records. This album and Music of My Mind, released earlier the same year, are generally considered to mark the start of Wonder's "classic period".

title: The Slider
description: The Slider is the seventh studio album by English rock band T. Rex, and the third since abbreviating their name from Tyrannosaurus Rex.

title: The Eagles
description: Eagles is the debut studio album by American rock band the Eagles. The album was recorded at London's Olympic Studios with producer Glyn Johns and released on June 1, 1972, by Asylum Records.

title: Exile on Main Street
description: The English rock group the Rolling Stones have released 31 studio albums, 12 contemporary live albums, 27 archival live albums, 28 compilation albums, 3 extended plays, 123 singles, 31 box sets, 51 video albums, 2 video box sets and 77 music videos. Throughout their career, they have sold over 250 million albums worldwide.

title: All Directions
description: All Directions is a 1972 album by The Temptations for the Gordy (Motown) label, produced by Norman Whitfield. It reached number two on the Billboard 200, making it the band's most successful non-collaborative album on the chart, and became their twelfth album to reach number one on the Top R&B Albums chart.

title: Something/Anything?
description: Something/Anything? is the third studio album by American musician Todd Rundgren, released in February 1972 by Bearsville Records.

title: The World Is A Ghetto
description: The World Is a Ghetto is the fifth album by American band War, released in late 1972 on United Artists Records. The album attained the number one spot on Billboard, and was Billboard's Album of the Year as the best-selling album of 1973.

title: Close to The Edge
description: Close to the Edge is the fifth studio album by the English progressive rock band Yes, released in the UK on 8 September 1972 and in the US on 13 September 1972, by Atlantic Records. It is their last album until Union (1991) to feature original drummer Bill Bruford, who found the album particularly laborious to make and felt unable to contribute better ideas, which influenced his decision to join K

title: Billion Dollar Babies
description: Billion Dollar Babies is the sixth studio album by American rock band Alice Cooper, released on February 27, 1973. The album became the best selling Alice Cooper record at the time of its release, hitting number one on the album charts in the United States and the United Kingdom, and was certified platinum by the Recording Industry Association of America.

title: Catch A Fire
description: Catch a Fire is the fifth studio album by the reggae band The Wailers, released in April 1973. It was their first album released by Island Records.

title: Future Days
description: Future Days is the fourth studio album by the German Krautrock group Can, released by United Artists in late 1973. The album employed significantly more complex production than any other album in the Can discography, and explored a more ambient–influenced sound.

title: Aladdin Sane
description: Aladdin Sane is the sixth studio album by the English musician David Bowie, released in April 1973 through RCA Records. The follow-up to his breakthrough The Rise and Fall of Ziggy Stardust and the Spiders from Mars, it was the first album he wrote and released from a position of stardom.

title: Made In Japan
description: Made in Japan is a double live album by English rock band Deep Purple, recorded during their first tour of Japan in August 1972. It was originally released on 8 December 1972 in Japan, with a US release on 30 March 1973, and became a critical and commercial success.

title: Goodbye Yellow Brick Road
description: Goodbye Yellow Brick Road is the seventh studio album by British singer, pianist, and composer Elton John. A double album, it was released on 5 October 1973, by DJM Records.

title: Faust IV
description: Faust are a German rock band from Hamburg. Formed in 1971 by producer and former music journalist Uwe Nettelbeck, the group was originally composed of Werner "Zappi" Diermaier (b.1949), Hans Joachim Irmler (b.1950), Arnulf Meifert (b.1943), Jean-Hervé Péron (b.1949), Rudolf Sosna and Gunther Wüsthoff, working with engineer Kurt Graupner.

title: Selling England by the Pound
description: Selling England by the Pound is the fifth studio album by the English progressive rock band Genesis, released on 5 October 1973, by Charisma Records. The album was a commercial success in the United Kingdom, reaching No.

title: Space Ritual
description: Space Ritual is a 1973 live double album recorded in 1972 by UK rock band Hawkwind. It is their fourth album since their debut, Hawkwind, in 1970.

title: Raw Power
description: Raw Power is the third studio album by American rock band the Stooges, released on February 7, 1973, by Columbia Records. The album departed from the "groove-ridden, feel-based songs" of the band's first two records in favor of a more anthemic hard rock approach inspired by new guitarist James Williamson, who co-wrote the album's eight songs with singer Iggy Pop.

title: Paris 1919
description: Paris 1919 is the third solo studio album by the Welsh musician John Cale, released on 25 February 1973 by Reprise Records. Musicians including Lowell George of Little Feat and Wilton Felder performed on the album.

title: Solid Air
description: Solid Air is the fourth studio album by the British singer-songwriter John Martyn, released in February 1973 by Island Records.

title: Berlin
